turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Siegal, you may proceed.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
The petitioner, Vincent Joseph Spano, was convicted of a crime of murder in the first degree in the County Court, Bronx County, New York, was sentenced to death.
The sentence has been stayed.
Certiorari was granted by this Honorable Court on the 15th day of December, 1958.
The Court of Appeals of the State of New York affirmed the judgment of conviction by a vote of 4-to-3.
Now, may it please the Court, briefly the facts are these.

On January 22nd, 1957, the petitioner, Vincent Joseph Spano, was in a bar and grill and had a $10-bill on the counter when the deceased, one Frank Palermo walked in and took the bill off the counter and walked out of the bar.

Vincent Joseph Spano walked out after him, an argument started and Frank Palermo, a former professional fighter gave the petitioner Spano a most vicious beating, punching him down to the ground and kicking him in the head, leaving him in a dazed and bloody condition.
He became violently sick immediately, vomited right in front of him, was taken into the bar.
Someone there washed his bruises.
He went home, walked home, came back and went to the candy store that he was directed to go to by Palermo.
When Palermo gave Spano this beating he said, “This isn't all.
Bring the rest of the money to this candy store,” designating a certain candy store.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What did he mean by (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well, he had made a demand for certain money and all he had gotten, sir, was $10 off the bar.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, you mean (Inaudible) man claiming that he owed it or --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Not that he owed it.
We contend, sir, that it was a matter of tribute, was a matter of extortion.
Palermo directed Spano to go to this designated candy store.

That to anyone in that neighborhood, amongst those people, was known as the headquarters of Palermo and when Spano got in there, as the evidence shows, three gangsters were in the place besides Palermo.

Spano had gone home in his dazed condition, had gotten a gun, had walked to the candy store and at first fired a volley of two shots up near the top of the ceiling, no where's near or in the direction of Palermo.

The evidence shows that at that time, as the petitioner stated the door behind him closed or opened and he felt someone running towards him from behind, the three in the store closing in on him and it was at that time that he fired a volley of three shots and killed Palermo.
He then, as the evidence showed, left the scene and was missing for a period of about I believe it was 10 days or two weeks, something of that order.
It then developed that Spano got in touch with an attorney named Tobias Russo, a well-known lawyer in Bronx and arranged for Mr. Russo to surrender to the authorities.

In the meantime before the surrender, the District Attorney of Bronx County had presented the evidence that they had before the Grand Jury of Bronx County and obtained an indictment charging this defendant with the crime of murder in the first degree.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Where there eyewitnesses to the murder?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: There was one other.
There was one eyewitness, sir, a young boy I think 14 or 15 years of age.

The attorney, Mr. Russo made arrangements with the District Attorney, met the District Attorney in the street in front of the County Court House at or about 7:30 p.m. and there turned over, the petitioner Spano to the District Attorney, Personal Assistant District Attorney, Goldsmith and the county detective and then left.
The testimony shows that the Assistant District Attorney and the police talked the petitioner to a District Attorney's office.
This was about 7:30 or quarter to 8 p.m.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Did the District Attorney have an arrest warrant at that time?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Did the District Attorney have an arrest warrant?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well, it was a bench warrant notwithstanding, when the indictment was filed by the Grand Jury and accepted by the Court a bench warrant was issued.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Was the arrest made under that?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: I would -- I would say.
He was surrendered pursuant to the bench warrant and indictment.
The Assistant District Attorney interrogate or attempted to interrogate Spano from 7:30 until 12, or 12 o'clock in the morning and during all that time, Spano said, “I want my attorney.”
The District Attorney knew he had an attorney because only a few moments ago he had been surrendered by his attorney upon arrangement.
The District Attorney, nevertheless, knowing that he had an attorney and being told by Spano, “I have been advised not to make any statement except to give you my name.
I want to consult with my attorney.”
Nevertheless, they continued to interrogate and interrogate.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Had the District Attorney indicated to Spano's attorney that he intended to interrogate him?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: No, sir, not a word, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Had the -- Spano's attorney indicated to the District Attorney that he didn't expect him to be interrogated, had he given many instructions?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Not to the District Attorney.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Not to District Attorney.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Only to his client.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: To his client.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: All this --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: -- all this questioning took place after the indictment, is that correct?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: After the indictment, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: What was the provision of the bench warrant?
What did it require (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well, the bench warrant, reads as follows, sir.

“You are therefore commanded forthwith to arrest the above name and bring him before that Court to answer the indictment or if the courts have adjourned for the term that you deliver him into the custody of a sheriff of the county of or in the City of New York to the warden of the city prison of the City of New York.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, now, was that -- was that command complied with?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: They didn't take him and put him into the city prison.
They took him into the District Attorney's Office, sir, and questioned him until 12:30 and when they saw at 12:30 in the morning that he's still persistent, that he --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Were the courts open or was this term?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well, the Court was open, sir, but may I say this, sir.

The District Attorney is present as a custom in the Bronx that when a man is arrested on a warrant after indictment, no matter what time, he is brought before a county judge even if it's at his home because they all live right there in the neighborhood.
There wasn't any -- any trouble at all about getting a judge if they wanted him at that hour.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I gather the Court there it was termed time.
The courts were actually sitting during the day.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: That is right, the time was not called.
They were actually sitting.
They were going to sit the next morning at 10 o'clock.

Now, sir, after, 12:30, they saw they couldn't get anywhere, they took the petitioner up to the squad room of a police station and there continued to interrogate him and he there again, asked for his attorney, time and time again.
At time, one of the police officers testified that he couldn't find the -- a lawyer with the said name or telephone number in the telephone book.
At any rate, he never got an attorney.

At any rate, during that time, the District Attorney and the police sent a police officer named Bruno, who was a friend of Spano and to Spano a number of times, to tell him that he, Bruno, was in trouble if he didn't make -- if Spano didn't make a statement in this case, that his wife was going to have another child.
He might lose his job.
And he insisted that he make a statement.
The reason for that is this.

While the defendant or the petitioner was out before he arranged for the surrender, he called his friend Bruno and told him what had happened and said that Palermo had been on his back and had given him a bad beating and that he was dazed and so forth that he killed him and he wanted advice, that he was going to get a lawyer.
So now, they use this same friend, Bruno, to coerce Spano into making a statement.
They used him for the purpose of having him disregard, if they could, the advice and instructions of his attorney.

The District Attorney all of the time knew that this man was represented by an attorney, knew that there had been an indictment, knew that there was a judicial proceeding pending, yet nevertheless, continued to interrogate and interrogate until sometime around 3:30 a.m., after Bruno had left Spano for a few minutes, Spano said, “All right, let me make a statement.”
They called in a stenographer and they got a statement.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask you?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What were the lengths of time of continuous questioning undisputedly not -- not --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well, what we --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- had given answer to which the district -- which the -- which the District Attorney will have -- the District Attorney will have to agree.
That's what I mean by (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: My best opinion, sir, that the undisputed testimony is that it occurred between 7:30 and 12:30, then -- that might have taken a half hour to get to the squad room and then from about 1 to 3:30 the next morning.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Anyhow?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: That's in the District Attorney's Office.
Then they took him up to the squad room and they went to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible) during those -- those four hours (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well, they say they gave him a cup of coffee or they gave him a sandwich or something during that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The questioning --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: -- time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- continuous?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How many people were in the room at the time?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well, testimony was that they went in and out three ways.
Those three police officers.
The Assistant District Attorney was there all the time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Who did the questioning?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Mr. Goldsmith, the Assistant District Attorney and the police officers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was the stenographer present or just (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: The stenographer was only present, sir, at about 3:30 when they asked him to come in.
There was evidence of a case of a beating but I am not arguing that point now because that was denied and it's not -- it's a disputed of fact.
It's not an undisputed fact.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How long was the interruption after (Inaudible) which is --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: I would say in all about --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: -- half hour.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then it lasted until 3 o'clock?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: 3 o'clock, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: 3 o'clock.
And then was the stenographer called in?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He was there?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How long was that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: The exact time, sir, is 3:20 a.m. to 3:30 a.m.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The indictment has been returned a week or so maybe --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Prior, yes, sir.
There was a judicial proceeding pending at the time, when the bench warrant was issued.
He was surrendered pursuant to the indictment of the bench warrant.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In your State that the indictment specifies the degree of the murder charge does it?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is he indicted of the first degree murder?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: That's right, sir.
He was indicted for first degree murder.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: First degree murder.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Which as a matter of fact for meditation and deliberation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that do I understand he's been convicted as to a first degree murder?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: He has been convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to death.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is there any indication of physical abuse?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: There was, sir, throughout the record but it is not an undisputed fact.
They -- the police officers denied it and for that reason I refrain from arguing it here.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Did the admissibility of his confession go to the jury?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, over objection, the admissibility went to the jury but not on the question of the absence of counsel or the demand for counsel.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, what I was wondering was whether your position here turns solely on the absence of the counsel or whether you make a broader contention that absence of counsel taken in to consideration that the whole -- the whole setting should have excluded his confession --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Absence --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- as a matter of due process?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Absence of counsel, sir, plus the fact that there had been an indictment, plus the fact that there was a bench warrant issue, plus the fact that there was a judicial proceeding in being plus all of the other circumstances.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do you claim this is a coerced confession?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: In -- in that light, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, I don't understand what you mean in that light.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well, it's a coerced confession.
May I say this.
It's a coerced confession in the -- in the sense or in the language of Judge Desmond of the Court of Appeals in the dissenting opinion.
And may I answer this way, sir?
Well, Judge Desmond said this, “Usually, of course, the test for admissibility of a confession is voluntariness and usually voluntariness is a question of fact for the jury.”

But one of the senses in which the courts used voluntary, a confession or incriminating testimony taken from a defendant without warranting of his rights, during the progress of a criminal cause against them is not voluntary since in such a case the fact is undisputed.
The question is not one for the jury but a constitutional question of due process, an undisputed fact.

Some violations of rights, are too fundamental to be excused by a jury or layman, directly and frankly violated here with two such rights, the right to have the advice of lawyer at every stage of a Court proceeding and the right not to be forced to testify against oneself during such a proceeding.
Now, may it please this Court, I'd like to read just a bit further from Judge Desmond's opinion.
Now, we accept as evidence a confession extracted during the very course of a judicial proceeding after indictment and surrender on a bench warrant.

When the time for investigation has passed and when the prisoner no longer is a suspect, but now a defendant held on the Court process awaiting trial has retained counsel who has warned him not to give evidence to the public authorities.
A citizen learning that he has been indicted and that a bench warrant is outstanding against him consults an attorney.
The attorney confirming strictly to his professional duty instructs his client forthwith to surrender, arranges for surrender to the representatives of the District Attorney's Office.

The lawyer accompanies his client to the place of surrender, warns him not to make any statement then leaves his client in the custody of the officers justifiably confident that the client's rights are safely under the protection of the Court and all of its mandate.
The prosecutor in his brief on this appeal reminds us that Spano's attorney could have waited until 10 o'clock the next morning and surrendered his client to the County Court.
Of course, he could but as we shall show defendant's rights and immunity would be no different since whether at 7 p.m. or 10 a.m. the surrender was to the Court in obedience to the process.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask you --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- whether you can think the case would have been different that the same questioning, for the same duration under or the statement you raised on certain circumstances at the same time by the same personnel had been carried on and a confession then secured that Spano have had no lawyer?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: I don't -- if he had no lawyer?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose that?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: I think the situation would have been the same if he demanded a lawyer, if he asked for a lawyer so long as there was a judicial proceeding in there.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He was advised that the didn't have a lawyer or that he was that the confession was involuntary which is --

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: The confession was involuntary because he was deprived of his right to counsel during a judicial proceeding.
We submit most respectfully that there was a judicial proceeding.
This was a -- at a pretrial stage.
He was entitled to a counsel at every stage of the proceedings.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that the questioning itself do you think was not -- did not deprive the confession from being voluntary?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Not in that sense if we're talking about physical coercion.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This Court hasn't restricted coercion, or physical coercion.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: But this Court --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This Court hasn't held that you require a beating.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Not of those elements separately but this Court has held I believe in the Crooker case that although in that case, the Court held that it was not a violation of due process to deprive a defendant of counsel but that was at the time of arrest and a -- that was at the time of arrest before there was an indictment.
And this Court held I believe that to say that the deprivation of counsel in such a stage would be a violation of due process would hamstring the authorities.
But in this case, there is no such question and we draw that distinction if we may.
We say they have investigated the petitioners' no more a suspect, he is now a defendant.
There is a formal accusation against him.
It's pending in the Court.
He surrenders pursuant to that bench warrant.
Therefore, at that time, at the moment of the filing of the indictment, two things happen.
Number one, he has an obligation to defend and number two he has the right to attack and at that moment, he certainly could come into Court.
He is in Court.
There is a judicial proceeding and he could make any kind of a motion that he wanted at that moment.
He is certainly -- is entitled to counsel.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: The indictment on which he was tried, was that indictment that had been found prior to this episode?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: That is right, sir.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: No superseding indictment?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: No superseding indictment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose the -- the judge had been -- and instead of reporting to the District Attorney -- the District Attorney has brought in the judge and it's closed the door, made the same inquiry to the District Attorney in the office, would that change the situation?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: It Wouldn't change.
It would be a violation I would say of due process.
I don't think if either the judge or the District Attorney or anybody else has the right to question the defendant after the indictment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose the judge has done before indictment?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Well (Voice Overlap) it might raise some other questions before indictment.
It might raise some other questions.
But if it was a formal charge laid against the defendant, I still believe that he was entitled to counsel on his demand for a counsel.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He'd already been indicted.
But suppose the judge after this case had been set on to trial, and he just shuts the door, let the District Attorney ask the big question will that violate the due process?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: I would say, sir, definitely.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In order to get rid of the case?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: I would say, sir.

I would say that in this case if the attorney or the petitioner had been sitting in the courtroom with the petitioner at five minutes to ten waiting for the petitioner to be arraigned and before the clerk of the Court had an opportunity to call the petitioner for arraignment, the District Attorney or the police had snatched the petitioner out of the courtroom, and taken him into a side room outside of the hearing and presence of the defendant and question him, that certainly would have been a violation of due process and the District Attorney's contention that he had a right to question because it was before arraignment, we respectfully submit has no merit because they certainly cannot delay arraignments and say that because the physical act of arraignment didn't take place, they have a right to question.
We submit most respectfully to this Court that from the moment of that indictment that defendant was in Court when he surrendered pursuant to the bench warrant he was in Court.
He had a right to counsel and that his persistent demands throughout the seven or eight hours of interrogation that he wanted a counsel was a deprivation of due process.
Now, we most respectfully urge this Court to reverse the conviction and sentence of death.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Siegal, just so I understand you.

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He surrendered himself to be arrested.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is it not -- is it customary in New York to take the people who are indicted that way and to take them to jail, take them to the District Attorney's Office for questioning?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would -- I -- I couldn't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) I don't know.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Justice Black I couldn't answer that category because I'm not that familiar with what is accordant to other cases.
I do know that in situations where indictments have been found, people have been questioned before arraignment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, has it been taken -- is it the custom to take them to the District --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, they usually would be questioned in the squad room.
This was merely for the sake of convenience he was surrendered in front of the District Attorney's Office which happens to be in the Bronx Country Building and was taken up there.
He was rented two New York City Police Officers, the District Attorney was present.
This was a prearranged surrender.
It was at 07:10 p.m.
He was taken up there.
He was questioned casually.

He was federal, well fed, then about a quarter to 12, 12 o'clock he was taken to the 46th squad room which had the 46th squad having jurisdiction of the area wherein the crime was committed and he was questioned there again --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Who -- who questioned him there?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Detectives that questioned him there.
The District Attorney was also present.
There's no indication of an incessant questioning.
Then Patrolman Bruno was called in.Patrolman Bruno spoke to Spano.
Spano then gave what the record will reveal to be a clearly voluntary confession, substantially consistent to that to which he had already given prior to the surrender to Patrolman Bruno.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are you --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I just don't see you leap by the hurdle do you not when you say that the man has been under question for all these hours, at the District Attorney's Office, begging for a lawyer.
So you leap by the hurdle do you not and say that has to be voluntary.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Justice Black if I may, the record indicates that to only two people according to the record that he'd say, “I want my lawyer,” to Detective Ciccone in the 46th Squad and to Patrolman Bruno, to everyone else according to their own testimony, this is uncontradicted in the record.
He said, “See my lawyer.”
He did not say “I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He made that request to a lawyer (Inaudible)
The lawyer was there when he said “I need my lawyer,” wasn't he?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, he was not Justice Black.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The lawyer was never there, he didn't know --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The lawyer surrendered him to the District Attorney.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm talking about the District Attorney's lawyer.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Oh, no -- the District Attorney did not appear in the record that he said to the District Attorney “I want my lawyer”.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, did he say it while the District Attorney was there?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That does not appear in the record.
Only Detective Ciccone and Patrolman Bruno indicates that he said to them he wanted his lawyer.
There is no evidence in this record, to the best of my recollection I think my recollection is accurate.
That he said to the District Attorney, “I want my Lawyer.”
There's no evidence of that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But isn't -- I thought your emissary told us that the District Attorney or Assistant that (Inaudible) throughout the interrogation while others came in and out of the room.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That does not appear in the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does -- does it appear from the record?
Mr. Siegal said that the -- the interrogation whatever you should make it lasted between (Inaudible) to about (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, there was --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That you challenge that?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, there was a hiatus there of about 45 minutes to an hour because of the fact that they were fed and sandwiches --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No that was about 11 o'clock p.m. Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does the record give the time?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Definitely, there are testimonies for that and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are you saying that if we want to reach the record for (Inaudible) of the -- what took place that justified with the trial that an interrogation in the District Attorney's Office one at a time that it isn't from 07:30 to 12:30 --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- from the time that it wasn't persistent.
One would find that on the whole if you said a little while ago that it was casual.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I think that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that the preoccupation was in a total to you to getting him to just make a confession.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would not say that.
I would -- the last statement I could not agree with.
I think that they were certainly interested in getting a statement.
What --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did he just -- what -- what would it be?
Did they discuss that (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Oh no, no.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What did they talk about?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: For example they asked him about a red mark on his head.
He indicated to them that because of his baldness he suffered from a -- a disease.
Later at the trial it indicated from his own doctor that he just -- that he suffered from --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: According to your reading of the record, how many hours is that transaction in the District Attorney's Office to take place?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would say from about 7:30 to 11 and perhaps --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That can't be four hours, three and a half hours.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: And then -- then there was a meal and thereafter -- it is difficult to ascertain whether he was requesting or whether he was just transported to the 46th Squad.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But the testimony at the trial in regard to what took place during those hours between 7:30 until 3 whatever the intermission (Inaudible) that the preoccupation of the questioning related to the transaction between other than this unfortunate murder.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would say that certainly it would be improper of me to say that they were not anxious to get a confession in the sense that they wanted to verify the statement that they had already received from Patrolman Bruno.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you're saying if we had nothing but that that this would not fall in within -- that this would not satisfy, or this would not be condemnable under the Fourteenth Amendment in the light of our case here, correct?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That is correct, Justice Frankfurter, that's my position.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is your position?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, that reversed on what the record may --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That -- that is absolutely --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Absolutely correct, Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, what do you say so that then from your point of view, there are really two questions in this case.
One, judged by the criteria of our decisions, for this -- on this side or on the other side for inadmissible confession under the Due Process Clause.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Number two, if this was a capital case then he is entitled to have a lawyer.
That means at some stage and for some purpose number two, order the trial with that protection of the Due Process Clause the protection of a lawyer.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That is correct.
Now, I would say that if I can just hope this one particular point that I think this case raises that was not raised in the Crooker or the Cicenia case -- cases that here we have an indictment.
Does the fact of an indictment ipso facto alter the situation so that federal rights are violated by questioning?
Now, we have seen cases, Lisenba against California where a man is taken out of jail and questioned by an invalid court order and yet the -- the conviction there was upheld.
We have seen cases about that.
Now, does the fact of an indictment, in fact, I can't answer this question.
Thus to the best of my knowledge, it's one of first impression on this Court.
Does an indictment ipso facto endow a man with rights superior to those to which any other accused would be entitled?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But Judge Desmond's opinion indicates one consideration on restraints namely the difference between this case and the (Inaudible) case in your court in the Court of Appeals, namely, where a man is detained as a witness, he does not know and has no reason to know or believe that his state is that of an accused with all the difference that that make in the witness of an accused.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, that that may be a fact which in the totality of the situation makes a difference.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He asked that question merely because if a man goes in and talks to him about, he happened to be a very literate or literate person, we discuss (Inaudible) problem and that's the reason of indictment, wouldn't not make or that make -- that make an involuntary confession?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The Perez (ph) case, Justice Frankfurter, the -- the material witness there was in the custody of the warden of the city prison or with the civil --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He was a witness --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: -- prison rather.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He was a witness, clearly.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's is correct now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He was not an accused, he did not -- he did not stand in the position of a man over whom the (Inaudible) sought of a conviction for murder --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- was upon him.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That is correct.
Now, of course, in the Perez (ph) case, we do not have a situation where the man was legally and properly in the custody of the police authorities.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But when you say that, when -- when I ask you, when a lawyer surrenders a client, charged with murder I suppose that that means nothing more than murder is not a bailable offense I assume in New York.
Is it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, it's not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Very well, he surrendered him because his -- his client was not -- he can't get bail and there he simply says he has surrendered his body completely should be put in jail.
But what consequences follow the surrender?
What indications are there beyond that?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But is he not bailable and he doesn't want to escape, he doesn't want to be a fugitive and he assessed it that way, surrendered him.
That's all it means --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- assumedly.
May I involve that?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, of course --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It doesn't mean go ahead and pressure him all you please doesn't it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No it doesn't necessarily.
Now, he had to be booked.
He had to be finger printed and photographed.
That is true whether the man is under indictment or not.
He must be arrested on the indictment on the New York Law.
Now, what if this had occurred during that course?
He was detained here for the purpose of booking primarily.
Now it's true in the District Attorney's Office since he was surrendered that was convenient to take him there.
I might add this, Justice Frankfurter, that there is a detective squad of the New York City Police Department that has headquarters in the District Attorney's Office.
It's true the questioning here happened to take place in the Office of Assistant District Attorney, Goldsmith.
But two New York City detectives to whom he was surrendered were present.
They were then brought to the 46th Squad.
Now the -- a petitioner here urges that if there had been no indictment and I believe I translated his intentions and his sentiments correctly.
He would have no quarrel or whatsoever with this situation.
In other words, if 50 people saw Spano shoot Palermo he obviously would be the prime suspect.
Yet, if he had not been indicted petitioner would say that perfectly all right to question them all you want, but if you indict him then you can't do anything.

Would it be morally correct for the District Attorney here Justice Frankfurter to have withheld an indictment merely to get a statement and then get the indictment when he had all the evidence he needed for it?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That I meant for a clause by that kind of analogy for our petitioner.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I -- I'm merely urging it, Justice Frankfurter.
I hope that you don't say --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do we have the record -- trial record in this Court?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Oh of course we do.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The stenographic form?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, in -- in printed form.
The people supplied me --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I see.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: -- with some copies and the petitioner.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is in the Attorney's Office?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, I believe there are 10 copies.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Enough for all of us?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I think 10 copies were filed with the Court, if the Court needs any additional we have --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There is --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: But I believe 10 copies were filed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I take it from what you say there is no dispute between you that at the time this man was surrendered, the District Attorney's Office knew that he had a lawyer.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No question about it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No question about it that and there is no question that they knew he's been indicted.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No doubt about that, too.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that he was being surrendered pursuant to a bench warrant issued on the indictment.
There's no dispute that.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, there was -- there'd be some question as to whether he knew there was a bench warrant outstanding.
He may have known, he may not have known.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, he knew he was being surrendered by his lawyer pursuant to an indictment the first time (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, he did not.
There's no evidence --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: -- of that whatsoever.
In fact in New York it is a misdemeanor to disclose the fact of indictment prior to a man's --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What did the District Attorney think he was being surrendered for?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, Spano himself contact this -- now that this -- I -- I must go -- the record to answer that if -- if --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But doesn't the record show it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The record does not specifically show whether he was surrendered pursuant to a bench warrant or not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But certainly --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: -- point.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- the District Attorney knew that there was an outstanding --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That is correct, that thought --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That -- that's conceded isn't it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's conceded.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That there was an outstanding indictment --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- and the bench warrant was issued on that effect.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Completely conceded.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's what I was asking you.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, I thought you meant that the defendant --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, I was asking whether District Attorney --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Oh no question about that, I'm sorry if I gave you the -- I didn't mean to mislead you at all.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I may have just spoken to myself.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Right.
Oh no -- no doubt about that at all, Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When was the confession and this confession to prove?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The day before his surrender of February 3rd at about 9:20 p.m.
He telephoned Bruno whom he had known for a number of years.
Told him what he had done.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black

That does not appear exactly what the further instructions were.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. -- Mr. Anolik, in your brief --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That would be my position.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- in here.
But you don't -- you don't -- as it was authenticate that.
You simply almost take it for granted and you rely talking on what Justice Brennan said.
But clearly it seems to me that, that's a vital part of the case -- that's on page --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, I'm -- I'm familiar with that, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If -- if this -- if this confession, lawyer or no lawyer, murder or no murder was voluntary, even legal, constitutional the Fourteenth Amendment said, is that qualified?
That that is the only other problem is the denial of access to his lawyer (Inaudible) but you sort of take that for granted?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, I don't think the petitioner even seriously contradicts that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That issue was submitted to the jury, was it not?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It was fully submitted and as a matter of fact --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The petitioner doesn't question the instructions under which he was in submitted to the jury, does it?

turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Not the instructions but he --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that issue was -- were resolved by the jury wasn't it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, there's nothing in the record to indicate, Justice Frankfurter that there was any agreement that he would not be questioned.
On the contrary, since he was admonished not to say anything, as the New York Court of Appeals recognizes, apparently interrogation was anticipated otherwise why admonish him to say nothing.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What from your -- your reading of the record, what -- does the record show as to a demand by him to see his lawyer to have him present to consult him?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I say this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was there a denial of such a request?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Detective Ciccone testified that Spano asked to see his lawyer.
He said he then attempted to locate his lawyer's name in the telephone book and was unsuccessful.
The attorney --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was the lawyer a known member of your bar?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: He was known but this was the 46th one.
He was then -- he then asked Patrolman --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That was --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is that?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What's the significance of that?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, in other words, Detective Ciccone wouldn't necessarily have known this particular lawyer.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, he might not have known (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct, but --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Wouldn't there be a responsibility in -- in having him take steps so that he would find out where that lawyer was?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Justice Frankfurter, all I can say is that the record indicates that Detective Ciccone alleges that he attempted to find the name in the telephone book and could not.
So, there's nothing further --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The insisting could certainly do him because he had received Spano from the --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The attorney didn't he?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: But that is assuming, Justice Brennan that a direct request was made to the -- the Assistant.
But there's no evidence of that at all.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you -- you think that a policeman would ask him -- to whom a -- an indicted person gives the name of his lawyer, who can't find it in a telephone maybe because he didn't get the spelling right, is absurd when taking no further step (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No.
I -- I think that the -- the -- I think, the police officer should be reprimanded that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, but it could -- if it's a question of getting protection from legal advice, legal advice that the -- the suffering or rather the hurt, the denial that's involved in his right to get a lawyer reduces a State.
Every -- every police have the -- every prosecutor is part of the State for that purpose?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would agree.

If the Court, this Court has passed upon similar problems, Justice Frankfurter, not while on indictment was extant, that's true but certainly this Court has passed on in the Cicenia and the Crooker cases.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In the Crooker case, this isn't the Crooker case.
This is --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I know it's not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Very different situation.
Seeing the nature -- the individual had experienced -- it was almost that he was a lawyer himself etcetera -- etcetera.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, in the Lisenba case, there was a request for counsel and counsel was not furnished.
I believe in Stroble there was a question or there was a request for counsel and counsel was not --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But the question of having a counsel whether was if it was taken.
The counsel that was -- wasn't asking for a lawyer.
Not denying access to lawyer, what you have got?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, of course, in -- I believe in -- in Lisenba he had a lawyer and the -- it was -- they took him out on -- on May 2nd or something and questioned him --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There's a question there on whether it was or wasn't a voluntary confession.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct and I think the same issue would have to be faced here, Justice Frankfurter or that was not --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was this lawyer listed in the telephone booklet?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, question about it, he was.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He was?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It could have been due to a misunderstanding of the pronunciation of the name.
I don't know but I -- I'm not trying to justify Detective Ciccone, Chief Justice Warren.
Make no mistake about that.
I merely say that his testimony stands that he couldn't locate him.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What more advice did the lawyer have given if they called him and brought him up to than that which he had already given them and that which the man kept saying, ”My lawyer has told me not to talk.”

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That all he could (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's about all he could have done.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, maybe when you say that the lawyer had admonished him because he anticipated questioning maybe it'd be a little clearer, if you'd say because he feared he would be questioned.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's another -- another way of putting it, Justice Black.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, there's one more thing.
If the lawyer had been present, the lawyer would have interposed his will.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And imposed his will on his client as against the attempted assertion of will by the District Attorney.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's quite correct.

Now, of course, in State v. Bump which is a New Jersey decision cited on my brief, the court there indicates where a -- a somewhat similar but not identical situation obtained that while an attorney should be present to defend the client an attorney is not necessary to protect the client from his own voluntary statements.
And if this was a voluntary statement, then the people submit no federal right was produced.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But for how many hours after -- after the District Attorney and the police know that a man has -- has a lawyer and know who he is and -- and the defendant has protested that his lawyer has told him not to talk and he doesn't want to talk.
For how many hours can they question him in order to overcome his will in that regard and get the statement that they desire?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, I would say that -- of course, it's a difficult question to answer.
I would say that that's where the significance of a prompt arraignment might come into issue.
If this man had been detained, shall we say until the 6th of February, another full day and then the -- the confession obtained.
Then we might say that here they went too far.
But in this case, this -- this specific case they arraigned him promptly as soon as the courts reopened that morning.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, could they have continued to -- to interrogate him all night long and then brought him in at 10 o'clock with the same result?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I suppose, it would be conceivable but unlikely in view of the fact they have to have him fingerprinted, booked and photographed before he was brought into that Court and that was done.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
But I mean if they had done -- if they had done it, the situation would be the same as far as you can see as long as they arraigned him on time.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would say that, there again, assuming that the record indicates the confession of itself was voluntary, yes.
I'd have to say that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Even though he was protesting from -- from that time on until 10 o'clock in the morning that he didn't want to talk, that his -- his counsel had advised him, not to him, that he wanted to see his lawyer and so forth.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would say that to be consistent.
I have to say that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: But may I say this, Mr. Chief Justice Warren, that only two witnesses, Patrolman Bruno and Detective Ciccone ever testified that he asked for his lawyer that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: -- the other --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How many should he have to do when people are coming in and going out of the room?
Should he have to look at every man and tell him --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- specifically --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is it not sufficient for him to -- to say to whoever is in charge of questioning him that his lawyer has advised him not to talk.
That he doesn't propose to talk and -- and the client should do it.
And then for four or five hours, he -- he declines to make a statement for that reason.
Does he have to be meticulous about seeing that he made the same statement to every single one

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- of the people?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Of course, not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, then what -- why do you keep (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, I -- I --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- they only said it to two of the detectives who where there.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I -- I merely emphasize that from this point of view only, Justice Warren, that there is no direct evidence in this record that that request was made to the District Attorney or to the two detectives to whom he surrendered.
To them it's true.
They testified, he said, “You'd better see my lawyer about that.”
Now, that -- that is what the record says, Justice Warren.
I'm not attempting to characterize it one way or the other.
We're bound by the record.
There's no question about that.
Now, if -- if this meant that the questioning here, if it was voluntary, the people submit that there's no reason to invoke the Fourteenth Amendment because an indictment was extant.
If it was not voluntary, of course, there is obviously, a Fourteenth Amendment problem.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What the -- now, what is the practice in New York after arraignment where a man was incarcerated waiting -- what instructions do the police have as to whether it's admissible or mandatory or not?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Instructions are not the question at all after that.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do you say that everything up until arraignment (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Typically, that is what institutes the judicial proceeding.
Section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure of New York speaks of judicial proceedings commencing with the filing of an indictment but that section has reference to statutes of limitations.

And in only in that sense that a judicial proceeding start and certainly, I think that this Court will recognize that this interrogation was not a judicial proceeding upon that indictment as the dissent --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's precisely -- that's precisely what the petitioner is complaining about.
They said that after indictment what -- the only thing that can follow properly under the law and Constitution is an arraignment and the trial which are judicial proceedings.
And he says here that this --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- after an indictment instead they actually have these proceedings in the backroom of the station house.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Justice Stewart, if an indictment, as I say, precludes any questioning whatsoever, then, of course, my cause is -- is lost.
I concede that.
If this Court is prepared to say that the fact of an indictment in a state court precludes any further investigation, any further question then I -- I concede that my cause is lost.
But I respectfully submit that this Court is not -- is not required to make such a determination in view of its decisions and in view of this record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. -- before you sit down.
I'd like to ask you now that I have cast my eye over the pages of Bruno's testimony and I want to be sure that I haven't -- in my skimpy reading of it misread.

In the first place, there's testimony by him that Mr. (Inaudible) came at 4:00 a.m. not 3:00 a.m. as both of you have said, but much important than that, he made several efforts to get -- what's his name-- Spano as he thought, didn't he?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, he did.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And Spano stood his ground and wouldn't talk.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And Gannon sent him back again and again.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That -- that's correct.
He sent them back several times.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That there was a refusal to talk.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's a --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That there was an insistence by (Inaudible) friend Bruno to get him to talk.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I -- I would say that the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Lieutenant Gannon his superior, this fellow (Inaudible) he was brought down from the academy, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, he happened to live in the neighborhood.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.
But he wasn't part of the police --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Oh, no, no.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And somewhere they found out that he's a great credibility, they got hold of him.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well -- no.
He telephoned him --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Just --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: -- a day before this.
So they knew about this conversation, the day before you see.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he -- he stood his ground at the insistence of his boyhood friend, he wouldn't talk, several times that he says -- and at that time he told Lieutenant Gannon that they could get no statement out of this man, is that right?
I did and you went back into the room?
Yes.
At whose direction?
The Lieutenant and come -- what it was that he was said (Inaudible) don't worry etcetera.
(Inaudible) a long course of -- or an effort or rather serious continuing effort to have Spano speak freely, is that right?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And -- and he did, he was not forthcoming until to these -- these hours in which took place what you've said took place.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And finally at 4:00 in the morning if I have to understand you.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, the -- although the statement of the stenographer indicate an earlier time --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: -- there's some --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Anyhow --

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- one wouldn't (Inaudible) about an hour and a half.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is the course of events by which eventually this statement came to pass.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what you have just stated?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes.
That's correct.
If there are no further questions Chief Justice, Justices of the Court.
Thank you very much for your indulgence.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Siegal.
Are you finished?

turn.speaker: herbert_s_siegal
turn.label: Mr. Herbert S. Siegal
turn.text: Yes, thank you.
